title: Ox gores another ox – first offense
vignette: An ox that never gored before knocks over a neighbor's cow, breaking its leg.

options.text: Owner pays half the loss – his animal was a harmless “tam”.
Owner pays full – every owner must guard even a first-time gorer.

title: Ox becomes vicious (muʿad)
vignette: After three gore incidents, Ezra's ox strikes again.

options.text: Owner always pays full damages from now on.
Owner still pays half if he warned neighbors and tied the ox.

title: Pregnant cow gored – loss of fetus
vignette: A goring kills Rivka's cow and its unborn calf.

options.text: Pay damages for the cow only; fetus has no standalone value.
Compensate both cow and fetus—potential life has worth.

title: Goring a slave vs. a freeman
vignette: An ox kills a household slave.

options.text: Owner pays fixed 30 shekels regardless of slave's market value.
Payment should equal real market value like any human victim.

title: Pit in the public road
vignette: Yosef digs a six-handbreadth pit in the street. A donkey falls and dies.

options.text: Liability only if pit is at least ten handbreadths deep.
Any man-made hazard incurs liability, depth irrelevant.

title: Fire spreads by wind
vignette: Leah's bonfire sparks and wind drives embers onto neighbor's stack of wheat.

options.text: Owner always liable—fire is like his arrow.
If an unusually strong wind blew, it's an unavoidable accident.

title: Carrying fire across public domain
vignette: A porter walks with a torch that ignites a stall's awning.

options.text: Porter liable—should cover or shield flame.
Stall owner partly at fault for flammable awning in the street.

title: Chain reaction damage
vignette: A runaway ox knocks a jar which smashes a lantern that burns goods.

options.text: Pay full for every indirect loss—the ox set events in motion.
Liability stops after the first direct breakage.

title: Person causes injury (adam hamazik)
vignette: While texting, Dan bumps a passer-by who falls and breaks an arm.

options.text: Dan liable even if purely accidental—people must foresee hazards.
True accidents exempt if no negligence can be shown.

title: Payments for bodily harm
vignette: Assailant injures victim's leg.

options.text: Pay five categories: damage, pain, medical, lost wages, shame.
Only direct medical costs and lost wages—others are moral, not monetary.

title: Embarrassment to relatives
vignette: Hitting one's father leaves a bruise.

options.text: Same five payments apply to family as strangers.
Extra penalty; striking a parent adds spiritual offense beyond money.

title: False witnesses pay what they sought
vignette: Pair testifies falsely that Levi owes 1000 ₪.

options.text: When caught, they pay the full amount they tried to levy.
They pay only court fines; no private compensation to Levi.

title: Four- or five-fold thief penalty
vignette: Thief steals a neighbor's sheep and sells it.

options.text: Pays fourfold for sheep (five if it were an ox).
Double payment (kefel) suffices; extra multiple applies only to slaughter.

title: Walking a borrowed cow onto ice
vignette: Borrower leads cow over a frozen pond against owner's instructions; cow slips.

options.text: Borrower liable—ignored explicit warning.
Acts of God free the borrower of payment.

title: Robbery vs. theft distinction
vignette: Armed robber grabs laptop openly.

options.text: Robber owes principal plus shame damages—uses force.
Same liability as covert thief; distinction only affects divine penalty.

title: Returning stolen lumber now built in
vignette: Boards stolen, then built into a public bench.

options.text: Must dismantle bench and return original boards.
Pay value; tearing bench wastes communal resource.

title: Planting in another's field
vignette: Surreptitious farmer seeds wheat on vacant land; crop grows.

options.text: Landowner keeps crop and pays planter's expenses.
Planter keeps crop but pays rent for land use.

title: Benefit without loss
vignette: Tenant stays in unused attic; owner claims rent.

options.text: No rent—owner lost nothing.
Benefit requires payment even if no measurable loss.

title: Careless stone in one's pocket
vignette: Loose stone falls from pocket, cracking a shop window.

options.text: Liable—should secure personal items.
Exempt if stone fell without any negligence.

title: Partner's pit on joint property
vignette: Two partners share a courtyard; one digs a hole, partner's goat falls.

options.text: Digger liable—hazard created without consent.
Courtyard jointly owned; each assumed risk.

title: Ox startled by spectator
vignette: Child claps, ox bolts and gores passer-by.

options.text: Owner still liable—must restrain animal.
Spectator shares liability for provoking ox.

title: Dog drags torch into barn
vignette: Dog steals bread with ember, igniting stable.

options.text: Dog's owner pays full—fire is foreseeable.
Pays half—compound damage chain reduces liability.

title: Obstacle left in public domain
vignette: Work crew leaves planks in street overnight; cyclist crashes.

options.text: Crew liable—created hazard.
City partly liable for failing to inspect streets.

title: Ladder falls from roof
vignette: Homeowner's unsecured ladder tips, injuring pedestrian.

options.text: Full liability—negligent placement.
Partial; gusty wind was unforeseeable force majeure.

title: Artisan ruins customer's fabric
vignette: Tailor mistakenly cuts expensive silk off-pattern.

options.text: Pay market value for ruined garment.
Return damaged silk; customer absorbs some loss.

title: Hired watchman sleeps
vignette: Paid guard naps; thieves steal flock.

options.text: Pays full—sleeping is negligence.
Guard liable only if warned against sleeping.

title: Letter carrier loses documents
vignette: Messenger misplaces signed deed en route.

options.text: Carrier liable; essential document irreplaceable.
Pays only proven monetary loss, not sentimental damages.

title: Employer delays wages overnight
vignette: Farm owner promises daily cash but pays next morning.

options.text: Violation; must pay same day.
Reasonable delay acceptable if worker still on premises.

title: Ox and pit combination
vignette: Ox pushes goat into uncovered pit.

options.text: Pit owner and ox owner split liability.
Only pit owner pays; pit caused final harm.

title: Borrower's negligence count
vignette: Borrower leaves door unlatched; thieves take borrowed tools.

options.text: Borrower pays—failure to guard like owner.
Pays only if theft was foreseeable given neighborhood.
